loans.name: Amgalan

texts.en:
Amgalan is 49 years old and lives with his wife and only son in a house in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife is a teacher and his son helps with his business. 

He operates a taxi service in his town. He started his business in 2010. Previously, he managed a transportation service between Ulaanbaatar city and other areas of Mongolia. At that time he used to travel on bumpy roads with long hours, so it was quite a difficult job for him. Therefore, he decided to start the taxi service business, and he is planning to continue his business in the future. 

He is a friendly man who says, "I want to buy a car for my son in order to make him conduct his own business." 

He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase spare auto parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase spare auto parts for his taxi.

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim is a talented lady who operates a sewing business to support her family financially. She is very skillful and receives a good number of orders every month. She is the mother of three sons. Her eldest son has a garment-selling business. The next one sells cosmetics while the youngest one has a clothes-selling business. They all work hard and contribute to their family financially from their earnings. 

Shamim has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine which will help her produce quality work and fulfill orders on time. She has been operating this business for many years. She has a lot of business contacts. She hopes that an investment will help her business to grow further. 

She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application with Asasah. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Shamim.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Athman

texts.en:
Athman, a married man with three children, all of whom attend school, lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. School fees are his greatest monthly expense.

For the past 10 years Athman has operated a freshwater sales business, selling from door to door to his neighbours and passersby. His greatest business challenge is seasonality, but he dreams of becoming self-reliant in the future. Athman decided to work with Yehu because of its good customer relations, and with the Kshs 20,000 loan he will purchase a water pumping machine.

loans.use: to purchase a water pumping machine.

loans.name: Bat-Erdene

texts.en:
Bat-Erdene, 48, lives with his wife in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city . His wife is a cook in a cafe, while he manages a taxi service in his town, having started the business after working as a driver in a private company for several years. Within a short time period Bat-Erdene managed to stabilize his enterprise and bought a plot of land in order to start a vegetable growing and sales business in the near future. He also started construction work on his house.

A polite man who says, "I am planning to finish construction work on my house and start my vegetable business in the future," Bat-Erdene is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase some construction materials for his house.

loans.use: to purchase some construction material.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: Fe, a 58-year-old married woman who lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato with her family, is a farmer growing rice and corn to sell. She also raises pigs in her backyard. Both enterprises allow her to to help provide for her family.  Fe plans to use her loan to purchase farm fertilizers and pig feed and hopes to achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Handdorj

texts.en:
Handdorj, 70, lives with his wife and younger daughter in a house in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. His three children are grown up and live separately, but Handdorj always helps them to make their lives better. Because he manages a shoe repair business near a crowded and busy bus stop, he has many customers and earns sufficient money. He started his business in 2005 and is planning to continue it for the foreseeable future.

A responsible man who says, "If my children are happy with their lives, I will be happy too," Handdorj is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a new car for his son to start a taxi service.

loans.use: to purchase a new car.

loans.name: Ranahan's Group

texts.en:
Ranahan, 35, is the leader of this group. She is divorced and brings up four children by herself. She has three daughters and a son; the older daughters are at school and the other children are preschool age (under seven). Ranahan works as a nurse in the ambulance. This year she has just started cultivating agricultural products. She applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase onion seeds and fuel, which is needed for field work. In the future, Ranahan hopes to obtain a good harvest. With the profits received from selling agricultural products she wants to start building a new house. Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff. .

loans.use: to purchase onion seeds and fuel.

loans.name: Lhagvadorj

texts.en: Lhagvadorj is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in Hovd province, Mongolia. His wife stays home to take care of their children. Lhagvadorj manages a meat trading business in his town. He started his business in 2008. Previously he used to operate a meat trading business with his mother and gained much experience. Now he has his own business and is planning to expand it in the future. He is a polite man who attributes his business success to his good communication skills. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase an abundant amount of meat for his business.

loans.use: to purchase an abundant amount of meat for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a variety of molds.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel, age 36, has run a motorcycle transportation business for the past two years. The business earns him a monthly income of KES.13,500. He and his wife, Mary, have one child. Mary runs a retail shop business and they both help to support the family.

This is Samuel's first loan from KADET Ltd. He will use the funds to service and repair his motorcycles. Samuel intends to use the anticipated profits to buy another motorcycle and hopes eventually to own a fleet of commercial vehicles in future. His goal is to fund the education of his child.

loans.use: to service and repair his motorcycles

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac has operated a shoe design and sales business for the past three years. He also makes bags and wallets. He sells his products from his small storefront to neighbors and passers-by. Isaac dreams of building his own business premises in the future. The business's primary challenge is seasonailty.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan he has requested, he wants to establish a retail general store and to purchase bundles of wheat flour and maize flour to sell from his new establishment. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business. 

Isaac is unmarried and lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is his rent.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour and maize flour for a new retail store business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph has been a businessman operating a hotel for the last five years. He is 34 years old, married and blessed with two children.

He learned about KADET from the marketing done by the KADET staff in his area. Being this is his first loan, he planned to purchase goods, such as sugar, maize flour and tea leaves, for the hotel and furnish his business premises. He intends to use the returns from the loan to re-invest in the business and invest in farming.

Joseph’s dreams are to be the best and a well-known businessman in the area. He is an industrious man who can do well if funded.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of goods for the hotel

loans.name: Yhval's Group

texts.en:
Yhval is the leader of this group. She is 32 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she is bringing up a daughter and a son. Both children are preschool age (under seven), they go to kindergarten.

 Yhval works as the Loan Officer in the Financial Group “Kompanion.” Her husband is engaged in cattle breeding. Ten years ago, Yhval’s dad presented her a bull-calf and since that moment the family has been breeding cattle. The family also cultivates raspberries to earn additional money. Yhval applied for the loan because she needs additional financial funds to purchase mineral fertilizers, which are needed for the raspberry bushes. 

In the future, Yhval wants to provide her children a good education and have a good career.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Maher

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 36 years old, married and has three children.

Maher has had a food market since 2009, selling different kinds of food and soft drinks. He has a long experience in this field and a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $1500 to buy a tricycle called in Iraqi, "Stotp". It’s like a motorcycle with three wheels linked to box-like open car, to some extent a "pickup". He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a tricycle ("stotp").

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat is 46 years old, married and has seven children: three daughters and four sons. Only two of them are able to get education due to financial constraints. Her eldest son works in a private organization while the others stay at home. 

Nusrat is very supportive and does sewing and embroidery for her neighborhood clients to financially help her husband. She is very skillful in her work and can produce quality work which helps attract many customers to her.  She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her husband’s business of selling groceries. With the loan, her husband will buy groceries such as cooking oil, soap, spices, etc. in bulk which will help him fulfill the demand of his customers and make extra profits. 

He started this business 15 years ago and Nusrat is very hopeful that an investment will bring more profits to her family and help in improving its living standard. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nusrat.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business

loans.name: Haydar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 45 years old, married, and has two children.

Haydar opened an ice cream shop in 2007.He has three years' experience and has a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $2700 to buy an ice cream freezer. He is aiming to gain more profit so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy an ice cream freezer.

loans.name: Jassem

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 36 years old, married and has three children.

Jassem opened an auto repair shop in 2000, selling and repairing radiators. He has more than 10 years' experience in this field and has a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $2400 to buy a car welding machine and car oxygen sensors. He is aiming to earn more profit so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a car welding machine and car oxygen sensors.

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat sews clothes for her community clients to share the financial burden with her husband. She is also a very good housewife and does her household responsibilities very well. 

Her husband is a driver by profession and operates a rickshaw.  He provides transport facilities to his passengers and to school children. 

Nusrat has given birth to three sons. Her youngest son is studying in class 7 while others left their education after the 8th class. Her eldest son sells rice while the 2nd one works in a factory.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. Her husband is currently driving a rented rickshaw and pays almost one third of his profits in rent. With the loan, he will buy a new rickshaw which will help him increase his profits. 

He has been attached to this business for the past 10 years and Nusrat is hopeful that an investment will help her husband increase his profits.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nusrat.

loans.use: To buy a new rickshaw for transportation business.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 32 years old, married and has three children. He has been a farmer for the past three years. He paid his previous loan well. He has applied for his third loan from KADET ltd, which he will use to buy farm supplies, such as fertilizers and seeds. 

With the profits generated, he plans to pay school fees for his children and re-invest in farming.

He dreams to be a well-known farmer. He is an industrious man who works with effort to attain more despite his limited resources.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Hamza

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, single, and lives with three family members. One of them works.

Hamza has had a shop doing photocopying and selling mobiles phone since 2006. He has two years' experience in this field and has a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $3000 to buy a photocopier and a generator and to make shelves for his shop. He is aiming to earn more profit so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a photocopier and a generator and make shelves for his shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a basin and to expand his purchase of fish.

loans.name: Jetinah

texts.en:
Jetinah, 49, is a married mother of three school-aged children who all attend school. She is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where she has been farming for 10 years. She employs five farmhands. Her mixed farm produces maize, beans, millet, milk and eggs, which are all sold locally. She also earns income from her tailoring shop in the same town.

She has requested this loan of 61,200 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the living standards of her family. She faces the challenge of fluctuation in the prices of her products especially during the off seasons. She plans to expand her farming by acquiring at least two dairy cows and planting more Napier grass.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Issam

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 34 years old, married and has four children.

Issam has had a shop since 1991 where he works on auto plumbing. He has good experience and a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $3000 to renovate his shop. He is aiming to earn more profit so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To renovate his shop.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is from the village of Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 36 years old. Mary Jane is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, breads, biscuits, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mary Jane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Mary Jane from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a divorced woman with 2 school-going children. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.  

For the past 4 years, she has operated a beauty salon business; her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is seasonality; during the holiday season she experiences a large number of customers visiting the business. She dreams of establishing a hair-dressing school in the future.

With the 30,000 KES, she wants to purchase stocks of beauty products for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access business loans.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of beauty products for sale

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 51 years old. Asuncion is separated from her spouse and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Asuncion owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Asuncion has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Asuncion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Asuncion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Asuncion is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Asuncion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Rashida's Group

texts.en:
Rashida is 28 years old, married with two daughters. Both of them are very young and have not started their education yet.  She is a housewife, staying at home and doing her household tasks. She has good administrative abilities and manages her household expenses very well. 

Her husband is a welder by trade and operates a welding shop in the market. He welds and repairs iron, steel items, machinery and spare parts with the welding machine. He is known as an expert in his field and has a good number of clients who request his services regularly and pay reasonable rates.
 
Rashida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. Through the loan, he will buy a new welding machine to be able to provide better quality welding services to his clients. His current welding machine doesn’t work well and needs a replacement. 

Rashida hopes that by purchasing a new welding machine her husband will be able to increase his profits which will help Rashida save some income for the school admission of her elder daughter who is of school-going age. She is very confident that her husband will successfully be able to improve the condition of his business.  

Rashida is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application to Asasah. In the previous loan year, she has established a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rashida.

loans.use: To buy a new welding machine.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is a married woman who owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her husband works at the Kenya ferry services earning to contribute towards the family's basic needs. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.         

She has operated a cosmetic shop for the past 7 seven years, selling to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she also operates a business of selling clothes which adds up to her other source of income. Riziki faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of becoming a supplier of beauty products in the future.

With the KES 60,000 she wants to purchase stock of beauty products for her cosmetic shop and bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase stock of beauty products for her cosmetic shop and bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Arsenio

texts.en:
Arsenio is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. He is 53 years old. Arsenio is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Arsenio owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling vegetables like cabbages, carrots, potatoes, squash & ginger in the local community. Arsenio has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Arsenio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Arsenio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Arsenio is requesting a new loan of 26000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables like spices, carrots & potatoes. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Arsenio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables like spices, carrots & potatoes.

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Linet

texts.en:
Linet has been operating his clinic in her area of residence, she is 36 years old, married with three children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by the KADET staff during their marketing. She is applying for her first loan, with which she plans to increase her stock of drugs for her clinic.

She hopes to progress by opening a bigger clinic. She is hard working woman who can do more if resources are available.

loans.use: to increase her inventory of drugs.

loans.name: Kitovu Youth Development Association Group

texts.en:
38-year-old Magidu, a hardworking father of 5 buoyant kids, has been in the food sales business for the past decade. He plies his trade in the many food markets in Kayunga district. He trades mostly in cereals, but does not limit himself to only cereals. He also sells coffee, rice and beans. 

Magidu says he started in this business through the persuasion of close friends.  What has played in his favor through the course of the last 10 years is the fact that he is a farmer. This means that most of the crops he sells are from his small farm. Magidu says this business generates for him 70,000 shillings monthly in sales profit. With this loan, he says he is going to purchase more bags of coffee to resell.

loans.use: to buy coffee to resell

loans.name: Tuyên's Group

texts.en:
Tuyên is a 32-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Tuyên  is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Đồng Thôn nhóm 19 (19).

Tuyên  is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To make a living, she raises pigs for sale.  She has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

Tuyên  joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.    She is requesting a loan of 5,152,000 VND to purchase breeding livestock and pig feed.  The will be her 1st loan from SEDA.  Tuyên  plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to pay tuition fees for her children.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Tuyết  is a 19 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business, which makes items such as beds and wardrobes.


2.  Tuyến  is a 23 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business.


3.  Lợi  is a 28 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her pig and chicken raising business.


4.  Năm is a 27 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her chicken raising business.


5.  Viên  is a 35 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her pig raising business.


6.  Yến  is a 21 year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her chicken raising business.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Tuyên  20203040126 là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Tuyên  là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Đồng Thôn nhóm 19 (19).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán.  Tuyên  thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Tuyên  kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Tuyên  đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND để nuôi lợn và mua thức ăn cho lợn.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Tuyết  là 19 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


2.  Tuyến là 23 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


3.  Lợi là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Năm  là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Viên  là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


6.  Yến là 21 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to buy pig feed and breeding livestock

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 45 years old. Carmelita is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling vegetables like cabbages, carrots, squash & papaya in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Carmelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables like cabbages, carrots & squash. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Carmelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Unda

texts.en:
Unda is a single man who lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is his rent bill. 

For the past 3 years, Unda has operated a shoe designing business, selling in a shop to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He dreams of becoming self reliable in the future.

With the KES 40,000, Unda wants to purchase materials for designing shoes and also to establish a vegetable selling business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for designing shoes and also to establish a vegetable selling business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a generator and a new cooling device.

loans.name: Ana Lucila

texts.en:
Ana Lucila is from the village of Western, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 48 years old. Ana Lucila is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Ana Lucila owns & operates a mini-restaurant, serving a variety of different meals to customers like afritada, caldereta, halang-halang & fish soup in the local community. Ana Lucila has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ana Lucila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ana Lucila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients & working capital. Ana Lucila is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Ana Lucila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Honeylee

texts.en:
Honeylee is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 23 years old. Honeylee is married and has 1 young child. To make a living, Honeylee owns & operates a motorela or habal-habal services business for local community members. Honeylee and her husband are also planting and harvesting corn. Honeylee has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Honeylee joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Honeylee has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorela service. Honeylee is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the service & to buy corn seeds for the farm. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Honeylee from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past 8 years, Fatuma has operated a food vending business, selling by retail to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Richelle

texts.en:
Richelle is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 34 years old. Richelle is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Richelle owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, dried fish, sugar in packs, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Richelle has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Richelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Richelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Richelle is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & rice per kilogram. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Richelle from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old married woman living with her husband and two school-aged children. She is from Lebanon. She has been working in her own grocery store since 2005. She sells dairy and daily products, in addition of all types of vegetables.  She works hard in cooperation with her husband who works as air-conditioner repairman to be able to pay the high cost of living. 

She has obtained two Kiva loans and has been an excellent client with payments on time. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase her store inventory in order to increase her sales and therefore her income. She is very positive and has been able to build a good business reputation since her business came into being.

loans.use: to increase her store inventory.

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is a 30-year-old housewife. She is a very active lady and does her household work very actively. Her husband operates a construction supplies business. He deals with different construction companies and supplies construction materials to them on order.  

Nasreen is the mother of two sons and a daughter. Both of her sons are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will buy construction supplies such as cement, bricks and sand in bulk which will help him fill larger orders on time and earn better income. 

Nasreen is hopeful that her husband’s business will grow by purchasing construction supplies in bulk quantity and it will result in better living standards for her family. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nasreen.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies for resale.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 37 years old, married and has six children.

Ahmad opened a shop selling chickens in 2005. He gained good experience. He has a good reputation and is well known in his area.

He is requesting $3000 to pay the annual rent for his shop and to buy a chicken cleaning machine. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 53 years old. Vilma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Vilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Vilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Pir

texts.ru: Пир проживает в районе Рудаки. Ему 51 год. Он женат, имеет 5 детей. У него средне - специальное образование, он столяр. По профессии работает 5 лет. Сейчас он занимается растениеводством. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. В основном он выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Pir lives in Rudaki. He is 51 years old, married, and has five children. He has a vocational education as a joiner. He has worked in his trade for five years.  Now he farms. He has vast experience in this.  He primarily grows vegetables. He is taking out a loan to buy seed and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 61-year-old married man living with his wife and two young children who are still attending school. He has 28 years of experience working as a car mechanic. In 2008, he opened a small shop where he sells car oil and batteries. His products are designed for all types of cars. Over the years, this old man was able to develop his work and expand his business operation. Today, he is requesting to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional products at good prices. He hopes that with the new merchandise, he will meet his business needs and be in the requisition of his customers. In the future, he hopes to enlarge his shop and add a new service: selling car spare parts.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

Lorena requests a new 20000 PHP loan to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her sixth loan from HSPFI.  Lorena plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional tools and products. He is certain that with these purchases he will be able to serve more customers. This will be his second Kiva loan, and we note that he has been a good client with punctual payments.

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old, single and lives with four family members. One of the family members works.

Salam has had a barber shop since 2009. He has three years of experience in this field, has a good reputation and is well known in his area.

He is requesting $1,500 to buy a split air conditioner and to make a sliding door for his shop. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a split air conditioner and to make a sliding door for his shop.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 36 years old and from the village of Tangaro, Catarman, Camiguin Province.  She is married with six school-aged children.  Mary Jane owns and operates a specialized retail store.  Her main source of income comes from buying and selling sweet potatoes in the local community.  She also makes and sells charcoal.  Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Mary Jane joined Kiva partner Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) to access financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business.  She successfully repaid a previous HSPFI loan of 15000 PHP, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital.  Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase additional sacks of sweet potataoes and wood to make charcoal.  This is her sixth loan from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI):

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy is 22 years old and married to Japhet, a business man.  They are blessed with three children who are five, three, and 10 months old.  Daisy runs a shop in Languse trading centre in Kapsabet.  She has been involved in this business for three years and earns KES 3,000 monthly.

Daisy applied for a KES. 25,000 loan from Kiva parnter the Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) Ltd.  This loan will be her first.  She plans to use the loan to purchase 50kg of sugar and four bundles of maize flour. The profits from the sales will be used to purchase livestock for her farm.

She hopes to purchase a plot of land and improve the the living standards of her family.

loans.use: To purchase sugar and maize flour for sale.

loans.use: to improve his shop’s decor and make some renovations

loans.name: Numonjon

texts.en:
Numonjon is married and has one young child.  He has a small store where he sells men’s shoes and clothing.  He runs the store with his mother, who encouraged him to start the business and is very supportive.  Numonjon has been in this business for three years. 

He is requesting a loan of $2000 USD to purchase more clothing goods.  The business is currently in its high season.  Numonjon believes that opening second retail business will give him an advantage over his competitors and provide more profits for his family. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy clothing for sale

loans.name: Alphonce

texts.en:
Alphonce is 60 years old and married with twelve children between the ages of 17 and 40.  Four of his children are currently in school.  Alphonce has a farm in Kitale in western Kenya that produces maize, bananas and millet that are all sold locally.  He has been in the farming business for the last forty years and employs one farmhand. He also earns income from his tailoring shop in the same location.

Alphonce requests an 80,000 Kes loan from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to expand his poultry business.  He will use the loan to purchase more chicken stock and poultry feed. The extra income from this loan will enable him to educate his children and improve his family's livelihood. He faces the challenge of diseases and poor market prices for his products. He hopes to have expanded his farm to seven acres with five dairy cows and an established poultry farm in the near future.

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, storeowners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands.

texts.en:

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general alteration and tailoring services such as pillowcase and bedsheet repair to local community members. texts.en:

He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonality. He is getting up early and baking lepeshka and other bread so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. All the ingredients like flour, salt and yeast he purchases in the local market.

Now due to high demand, Abdusattor wants to increase the number of his breads, so he is requesting $1700. The loan will be spent for purchasing  flour, and also coal for baking “lepeshka”. He deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving to him.

In 2008, Aikomae joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Aikomae is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods and beverages. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods and beverages.

loans.name: Safarali

texts.en:
Safarali is 55 years old. He is married and has five children. He is a hardworking man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children. He has great experience in cattle breeding because he has practiced it for more than ten years. With time, he has increased his sales and now he needs assistance for investing in his business. The business has been going well and he would like it to continue to grow.

Safarali applied for a loan of 12,500 TJS to buy young cattle. He and his family thank you very much for the support that you offer them in continuing this business and helping them give their children a better quality of life.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase young cattle.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is 45 years old and lives in Pasay City, Philippines. She is married and has three children, one of whom is working while the other two are still in school. Gemma is working hard to put her children through college, because like most Filipino parents she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can give their children.

Gemma makes a living by making clothing and hair accessories, most of which are knitted. She has been in this business for almost eight years and is very knowledgeable about the preferences of her customers, most of whom are neighbors. She earns about Php 4,000 a month.

To help her continue operating her business, she is applying for a loan of Php 12,000. She will be use the money to buy more fabric and thread. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 
 
Gemma dreams of having her own house and land someday. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners which gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn lives the village of Bura, Catarman, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 30 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For the last three years, she has made a living by running a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells canned foods, snacks, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits. She earns about 10,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2008, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid five previous loans and is applying for her sixth, for 20,000 PHP, to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to continue expanding her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Yusup

texts.en:
Yusup is 48 years old, married, and lives with his wife and four children. He grew up with agriculture, and his parents did the same work and he still works planting seeds. He grows seasonal crops on his land, working with the crops until it is time to harvest them. In addition, for extra income he raises cattle. This is his third loan from IMON International and we are happy to have another opportunity to assist him with the operation of his business. Yusup will buy seeds and fertilizers for his land with this loan.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock for her cosmetic business.

loans.name: Mamlakatkhon's Group

texts.en:
Mamlakatkhon is the leader of this group. She is 47 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she has raised a daughter and a son. The son, 26, works in Russia and the daughter, 16, studies at school. Malakatkhon works as a librarian at school. At the moment the family keeps three cows, and the profits gained from milk sales help the family meet their daily needs. Selling the dairy products, the family makes an additional $55 per month. Mamlakatkhon applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a calf in order to increase the number of cattle stock. In autumn she plans to celebrate her son’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel is 34 years old, married, and has three children between 2 and 12 years old.  She operates a retail shop to earn a living. She also sells cereals.  She has engaged in the business for five years.  She joined a group in Faulu Kenya which has helped her to interact with other entrepreneurs, and she has gained business ideas.  She hopes to expand her business premises and employ people in the future.  She has requested 50,000 KES to buy rice, sugar, cooking fat, beans and peas.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, cooking fat, beans and peas.

loans.name: Dimpna

texts.en:
Dimpna is from the village of Bura, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 57 years old. Dimpna is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling coconuts for copras (dried coconut for coconut oil) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately $238 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Dimpna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Dimpna is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts for copras. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts for copras.

loans.name: Asgalali

texts.en:
Asgalali is 48 years old, married and has three children, all of whom help on his farm when not studying in school. He works hard to improve his family's living conditions but faces hardships in the winter when his fields are largely dormant. He learned farming from his parents and is applying for this loan to improve his farm by buying fertilizer and other materials. He believes this will help him improve his crop and earn a larger income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and farm equipment.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Aisha lives in the Kawempe neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has seven children, none of whom are currently in school. For the last 10 years, she has made a living by selling green bananas.  She works seven days a week, selling her product in a local market. She is applying for a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bananas to sell to her customers. Her main challenges are transportation and rising prices for bananas. Her main goal is to buy a delivery van. She lives in a home that she owns and which has access to electricity but not piped-in water.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad, 40 years old, is a retired military man married to Kefah, a 40-year-old housewife. They have four children all under the age of 15 and they live in a rented house in Madaba. 

Mohammad opened a small food market beside his house after retirement to be able to have another income sources to support his family and his young kids. It has been a year now since he opened his business and it has been running successfully in the neighborhood.

Now Mohamad has applied for a loan to buy more goods from the suppliers and to redecorate the food market in order to attract more customers and to have the space to add new products or goods.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell and to redecorate the shop

loans.name: Shermamat

texts.en:
Shermamat is 50 years old, married, and has eight children. Shermamat comes from a humble family and, from a young age, he helped his father in the fields, which is why he never finished his studies. Despite that, he feels fortunate to be with his wife, who helps him with their farming business. Shermamat cultivates tomatoes, potatoes, onions, and watermelons. He is very thankful for what he has and, thanks to the dedication and support from his family, he can have a dignified life and give a better life to his children. At this time, he is requesting a loan, which he will use to buy more seeds and fertilizer that will help him cultivate more produce.

loans.use: to purchase the seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en: Hamida lives in the Client neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has one child, who is not yet in school. About a year ago she went into business running a bakery. She works seven days a week and is applying for a loan for 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more flour, oil and other items.  Her main challenges are transportation and increasing prices for the ingredients she uses. Her goals are to increase the amount and variety of items she sells, and acquire a van for pickups and deliveries. Hamida lives in a home that she rents which has access to electricity but not piped-in water. Her main monthly expenses are rent, medicines and food.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a bakery.

loans.name: Jenour

texts.en:
Jenour is from the village of Tagpako, Gingoog City. He is 21 years old and married. To make a living, Jenour owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, buying and raising pigs for resale. He also provides motorela or habal-habal (motorcycle transportation) services. Jenour has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately $209 a month for these activities.

In 2010, he joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. 

Jenour is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be his 4th loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy two refrigerators and to make a ceiling for his shop.

loans.name: Amor

texts.en:
Amor is from the village of Pahindong, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 36 years old. Amor is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling electronic loads and sim cards of several networks like GLOBE, SMART and SUN in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $285 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Amor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Amor is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional electronic loads and cell phone accessories. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional electronic loads and cell phone accessories.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 31 years old and single.  For four years, he has been operating a stationery shop.  His desire is to enlarge the business premises and get more customers.  Currently, he operates the business with one employee and hopes to employ more people.  James says that he has benefited from Faulu Kenya because he has managed to save his money and share business ideas with his group members.  He has requested 50,000 KES to buy toner, cartridges and printing paper.

loans.use: to buy toner, cartridges and printing paper.

loans.name: Swalehe

texts.en:
Swalehe is a married man with four children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past eight years, he has operated a charcoal selling business, selling at retail to his neighbors and passersby. In addition he also operates a motorcycle business which contributes another source of income. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. His dream is to expand his business in the future.

With the 40,000 KES he wants to purchase sacks of charcoal to resell and repair his motorcycle. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal and repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is from the village of Pahindong, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old. Jocelyn is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a mini-restaurant, serving a variety of different meals to customers, like adobo, bulalo and afritada, in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $186 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant.

Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients like meat and spices. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients like meat and spices.

loans.name: Zulfiya

texts.en:
Zulfiya works in a very successful fabric sales business. She operates a sales location where she offers a selection of trendy fabrics for sewing national women's dresses. Her business has a long history. She was able to start this venture nine years ago, and since that time her business has done quite well. She is quite an entrepreneur and we are happy that she has chosen to apply her talents in a business that helps women be even prettier. 

Zulfiya has requested a loan of 12,000 TJS to give her more working capital to use in her business. It will be exciting to see how Zulfiya's enterprise will continue to grow in the future as she's off to even greater success.

loans.use: to buy seasonal fabrics.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family. Margaret has a tailoring business.  She has been in this business for ten years, working one day a week, selling her products in a retail shop.    

She generates additional income through roasting yellow bananas and maize. The main business challenges for Margaret include the rainy season and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to open a tailoring school and also to start sewing bridal gowns.  She lives in a home that she rents where she has access to electricity but not to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.   

Margaret has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy clothing materials and threads.

loans.use: to buy more rolls of clothing materials and threads.

loans.name: Siah

texts.en:
Siah is 43 years old and lives in West Point. She’s a student in the eight grade and is married with three children between the ages of 11 and 20, all of whom are attending school. She has been selling used clothes and other assorted goods for the past eight years. She doesn't experience any difficulties about her business.

Siah is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. She plans to build her own house and send her children to quality schools.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mavlyuda

texts.en:
Mavlyuda is married with four children. She sells fabrics for sewing women's national dresses at the central market in Dushanbe city, and she has been in this business for eleven years. Extensive experience helps Mavlyuda choose the right kind of inventory and make good sales. She enjoys selling fabrics; moreover, this business brings her stable income. 

Mavlyuda would like to borrow 12,000 TJS to purchase a summer collection of fabrics. She has used IMON International loans before and considers them to be very helpful for her business.

loans.use: to buy seasonal fabrics.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is from the village of Pahindong, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Virginia is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business of making and selling banana and sweet potato kebab in the local community. She also makes and sells chicken and pork barbecue. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately $285 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. 

Virginia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed, like ripe bananas, meat and spices. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed like ripe bananas, meat and spices.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 27 years old, single and lives with 7 family members who 3 of them work.

Ali has a shop selling electrical items and household since 2010. He has 1 year experience in this field and has a good reputation and he is being well known in his area.

He is requesting $2400 to pay the annual rent and to add more inventory for his store. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality life.

loans.use: To pay the annual rent of his shop and to add more inventory for his store.

loans.name: Islom

texts.en:
Islom is 51 years old, married, and has three children. Seven years ago Islom decided to start his own business selling carpets. He began his own business with his hard earned savings as he had always wanted to be an entrepreneur. He is familiar with this business and provides good customer service. Islom has many clients and his business keeps growing. In order to increase the range of his carpets, Islom is requesting  a loan for 12,500 Somoni, which he will use to purchase more inventory.  Islom is sincerely grateful for your support.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

texts.en:

She faces the challenge of animal diseases and the high cost of animal feed. In the next five years, she hopes to have increased her milk productivity to at least 50 litres daily. Everlyn has requested a loan of 31,200 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable her to pay school fees for her 4 children, who are all attending school. Her biggest challenge in farming has been animal diseases, which are quite expensive to treat. She plans to expand her dairy business by acquiring more dairy cows and also by acquiring dairy goats.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is 23 years old and single.  He does farming to earn a living.  He has been farming for three years and employs two people on his farm.  Apart from farming, he also has a motorbike transport business.  Previously, he operated a kiosk.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, Bernard's living standards have improved.  He hopes to have a well-established business in the future.  He has requested a loan for 50,000 Kes to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
